Issues.Title: dpi aware PropertyGrid with expandable items draws tree caret on top of item name
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 5.0.102

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: No

**Problem description:**
A dpi-aware .Net5 PropertyGrid control showing a nested object (with **ExpandableObjectConverter** properties) draws the tree expand/collapse caret on top of the item name. The painting of the caret encroaches more and more over the item name as each level of nesting is expanded.
![Net5 aware](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11354336/104858996-cf0ed200-58d7-11eb-9ff2-799362de29f8.png)

**Expected behavior:**
A non-dpi-aware .Net5 PropertyGrid draws the caret properly in its own distinct space. The behavior is correct for a .Net 4.7 grid, regardless of dpi-awareness.
![Net5 non-aware](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11354336/104859035-db932a80-58d7-11eb-8f66-ca15839c1426.png)

**Minimal repro:**
The attached ZIP contains quite a simple example with a default PropertyGrid showing a class instance with a single ExpandableObjectConverter property reference to the same class as an example to create nesting. PNG screenshots are included to show the results for .Net 5.0 and 4.7 both aware and not aware. DPI awareness can be switched off/on in Program.cs.
[PropGridBug.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/5826998/PropGridBug.zip)

Issues.Title: .NET 5.0.2 release links are broken
Issues.Body:
The release page's doc links are broken

Goto https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/releases/tag/v5.0.2 and click on the `Release Notes` and `Install Instructions` links

* https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/release-notes/5.0/preview/5.0.2.md
* https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/release-notes/5.0/preview/5.0.2-install-instructions.md

Both result in 404 “This is not the web page you are looking for” 

However the [Core](https://github.com/dotnet/core/releases/tag/v5.0.2) link works as expect. I didn't test other links on the page.

Please fix

P.S. Same broken behavior for https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/releases/tag/v5.0.1. I didn't check other versions.

Issues.Title: MDI forms lost sub control box
Issues.Body:
(cherry picked from commit 8d9b1e6db90f4207037e467d24a213ded723ef0c)


## Proposed changes

With the deprecation and removal of `MainMenu` control in #2091 one of MDI scenarios got broken where both parent and child forms don't have `MainMenuStrip` property set nor have `MainMenuStrip` instance added to their respective `Controls` collection.

The fix restores setting an MDI menu via `WM_MDISETMENU` message to the parent form.

Resolves #3029

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

Migration blocker: customers who use MDI scenarios without main menu in both parent or child forms won't be able to minimise maximised child forms



## Regression? 

- Yes

## Risk

- Minimal.

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

| net48 | net5.0 |
| -- | --- | 
| ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/84857263-fab0ac00-b0ab-11ea-9639-a6db8f04cff4.png) | ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/104556980-916e3700-5694-11eb-933c-99dc2aa4f6d1.png) |

### After

| net48 | net5.0 |
| -- | --- | 
| ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/84857263-fab0ac00-b0ab-11ea-9639-a6db8f04cff4.png) | ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/104555480-1146d200-5692-11eb-8f6f-fa152091361d.png) |

## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual comparison of net48 vs net5.0 (current commit)
- CTI verified

Issues.Title: fix MDI clients lost control box icons
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->
(cherry picked from commit a40d23ce4227a25ae86b7f7bbaf9c7cff818fe5d)

## Proposed changes

During a cleanup in #2659 the `GetNativeMenuItemImage` forgot to set the size of the struct (previously done in the constructor when it was still a class). Since the return code of `GetMenuItemInfoW` is not checked it was not detected, effectively leaving the image at IntPtr.Zero and ignoring the call.

Resolves #4388
Resolves #4460



<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- migration blocker: in certain scenarios MDI apps become virtually unusable as the control box icons are missing, leaving users unable to restore or close child MDI forms

## Regression? 

- Yes, introduced in #2659

## Risk

- minimal

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->

Issues.Title: The code generated by the ListBox control is not consistent with Framework
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
3.1+

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No

**Problem description:**

<!--
    Describe the current behavior, what is wrong or not working as expected.
    Provide as much information as possible, including callstack for crashes/exceptions, screenshots or animations.
  -->
The generated code for ListBox1 have extra code: this.listBox1.ItemHeight = 15;
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15823268/104525385-e63a8080-55b4-11eb-8018-1cd886b658a0.png)

**Expected behavior:**
The generated code for ListBox1 should not have this code: this.listBox1.ItemHeight = 15;
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15823268/104525352-d1f68380-55b4-11eb-9bf4-fafbf11c85f4.png)


**Minimal repro:**
1. Create a Core winforms application.
2. Add a **ListBox** control to **form**.
3. Double click the **Form1.Designer.cs** file in Solution Explorer.
4. Observe the generated code of the **ListBox**.
Result: The generated code for ListBox1 should not have this code: this.listBox1.ItemHeight = 15;

Note from Dustin: ListBox.ItemHeight property. 
dotnet/winforms@4bca5b3/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/ListBox.cs#L596-L616
It has a `[DefaultValue(DefaultItemHeight)]` attribute and DefaultItemHeight is 13.
Note from Tanya: Our default value is not accurate anymore due to the default font change. 13 is the default for Microsoft Sans Serif, 8.25pt, 15 is what comctl32 listbox calculates for Segoe UI, 9pt. To confirm - change the parent control's font.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The code generated by the ListBox control is not consistent with Framework" (#4463)

Issues.Title: Some default values for control Heights are out of sync with the new default font

<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/docs/issue-guide.md -->

3.1+

We need to enumerate all DefaultValueAttributes to investigate if there are controls other than ListBox and DataGridView whose default sizes are affected by the default font change.

Related issues:
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/4461
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/4463

Issues.Title: The code generated by the DataGridView control has extra code for the RowTemplate.Height property
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
3.1+

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No

**Problem description:**

<!--
    Describe the current behavior, what is wrong or not working as expected.
    Provide as much information as possible, including callstack for crashes/exceptions, screenshots or animations.
  -->
The generating code for dataGirdView1 has extra code for the RowTemplate.Height property. For the newly created control *at 100% scaling*, designer should generate the same value as is defined by the DefaultValueAttribute

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15823268/104521807-77f4be80-55b2-11eb-9f38-b7e32eff005d.png)

**Expected behavior:**
RowTemplate.Height line should not be generated
 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15823268/104521910-b5f1e280-55b2-11eb-804e-5a05b8b8a195.png)

**Minimal repro:**
1. Create a Winforms .Net Core application.
2. Add a DataGridView to from designer.
3. Double click to open Form1.Designer.cs file in Solution Explorer.
4. Observe the generated code of the dataGridView1.

Note from Dustin: DataGridViewRow.Height has a [DefaultValue(22)] attribute, so the code-gen above is expected if the value is 25.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The code generated by the DataGridView control has extra code for the RowTemplate.Height property" (#4461)

Issues.Title: Implemented ScrollItemPattern for ComboBoxItemAccessibleObject (port to 3.1)
Issues.Body:
Fixes #4335
Fixes #4323

Based on changes from #4350

⚠️ A port of a .NET Framework servicing fix 

## Proposed changes:
- Implement `ScrollIntoView `method of `ScrollItemPattern`
- Fix getting of `Bounds`


## Customer Impact:

- Accessibility tools or users can scroll a combo box drop-down list to some item
- A user can see a correct item Bounds position when combobox scrolling, previously item position was not adjusted based on the scroll position
- These 2 bugs were approved for servicing in .NET Framework 4.8 in February release

## Regression?
- Yes (from .NET Framework 4.7.2)

## Risk
- Minimal

## Screenshots
### Before
- ComboBox items don't support `ScrollItemPattern`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/104170748-adfb3c80-5412-11eb-827f-9ac9ec022787.png)

### After
- ComboBox items support `ScrollItemPattern` - scroll the current item when invoking `ScrollIntoView`.
For example, in the gif below I call `ScroolIntoView` for the **9th** item, and the `ComboBox` ensures that the **9th** item is visible.
![4350](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/104171000-05011180-5413-11eb-8078-c3a540451b5d.gif)

## Test methodology
- Unit tests
- Manual testing
- CTI

Issues.Title: Implemented ScrollItemPattern for ComboBoxItemAccessibleObject (port to 5.0)
Issues.Body:
Fixes #4335
Fixes #4323

Based on changes from #4350

⚠️ A port of a .NET Framework servicing fix 
## Proposed changes:
- Implement `ScrollIntoView `method of `ScrollItemPattern`
- Fix getting of `Bounds`

## Customer Impact:
- Accessibility tools or users can scroll a combo box drop-down list to some item
- A user can see a correct item Bounds position when combobox scrolling
- These 2 bugs were approved for servicing in .NET Framework 4.8 in February release
## Regression?
- Yes (from .NET Framework 4.7.2)
## Risk
- Minimal
## Screenshots
### Before
- ComboBox items don't support `ScrollItemPattern` - `ScrollIntoView` is not available
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/104170748-adfb3c80-5412-11eb-827f-9ac9ec022787.png)

### After
- ComboBox items support `ScrollItemPattern` - ensure that the item is visible when invoking `ScrollIntoView`.
For example, in the gif below I call `ScroolIntoView` for the **9th** item, and the `ComboBox` shows the **9th** item.
![4350](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/104171000-05011180-5413-11eb-8078-c3a540451b5d.gif)

## Test methodology
- Unit tests
- Manual testing
- CTI

- Using Inspect

Issues.Title: fix MDI clients lost control box icons
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->


## Proposed changes

During a cleanup in #2659 the `GetNativeMenuItemImage` forgot to set the size of the struct (previously done in the constructor when it was still a class). Since the return code of `GetMenuItemInfoW` is not checked it was not detected, effectively leaving the image at IntPtr.Zero and ignoring the call.

Resolves #4388

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- in certain scenarios MDI apps become virtually unusable as the control box icons are missing, leaving users unable to restore or close child MDI forms

No, the bug does not happen in .NET 4.8

**Problem description:**
`DesignerHost.CreateComponent` throws `NotImplemetedException` with message: 
__This method/object is not implemented by design.__
<!--
    Describe the current behavior, what is wrong or not working as expected.
    Provide as much information as possible, including callstack for crashes/exceptions, screenshots or animations.

```

 	DemoConsoleNet5.dll!DemoConsoleNet5.MainForm.InitFormDesigner() Line 29	C#

 	[Native to Managed Transition]	
 	[Managed to Native Transition]
```

I am porting from .NET 4.8 to 5.0 a report designer that features a drag and drop design surface and uses WinForms. Everything works except for this.
I also ported from .NET 3.5 to 5.0 this project (https://www.codeproject.com/Articles/24385/Have-a-Great-DesignTime-Experience-with-a-Powerful) and everything works except for this.
Using dotPeek to step into the .NET 5.0 code I got as far as DesignerHost.CreateComponent, but I didn't find the method that throws the exception.

**Expected behavior:**
DesignerHost.CreateComponent returns the requested component

**Minimal repro:**
1. create a Windows Forms App using .NET 5.0 Framewok
1. create a class DesignSurfaceExt that inherits System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignSurface
2. initialize DesignSurfaceExt by calling ServiceContainer.AddService(typeof(INameCreationService), _nameCreationService); 
3. call rootComponent = (Form)designSurfaceExt.CreateRootComponent(typeof(Form), new Size(640, 480));
expected: CreateRootComponent returns a new Form
actual: DesignerHost.CreateComponent throws NotImplemetedException with message 'This method/object is not implemented by design.'

Issues.Title: ToolStripItemCollection.AddRange(ToolStripItemCollection toolStripItems) causes ArgumentOutOfRangeException as it deletes from source collection
Issues.Body:
This method cannot be used as it will always cause an ArgumentOutOfRangeException since items are deleted from the source collection while they are copied into the new collection.

Take this code in Form_Load()
    ContextMenuStrip1.Items.AddRange(EditToolStripMenuItem.DropDownItems)

Before it is executed, ContextMenuStrip1 has 0 items and EditToolStripMenuItem has 16. While it is called and the exception is triggered, both have 8 but alternating. I.e. ContextMenuStrip1 now has indexes 0,2,4,6,8,10,12,14 from the original EditToolStripMenuItem. EditToolStripMenuItem is left with 1,3,5,7,9,11,13,15.

The exception occurs because it is expected there will be 16 items to move, but only 8 exist in the array now.

Expected behavior: Each reference is copied into the target menu. Not removed from source.

Watches before: [https://pasteboard.co/JJhkD66.png](url)
After (at exception): [https://pasteboard.co/JJhkV9w.png](url)
(Apologies for random image site. Most are blocked by our corporate firewall)

This was tested on VB .NET 4.6.

I already have a workaround.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ToolStripItemCollection.AddRange(ToolStripItemCollection toolStripItems) causes ArgumentOutOfRangeException as it deletes from source collection" (#4454)

Issues.Title: Incorrect toolbar location when restored via `ToolStripManager.LoadSettings`
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/docs/issue-guide.md -->

Presumably all versions:
* .NET Framework: 4.6.1 (tested)
* .NET Version: 5.0 (tested)


**Problem description:**

Originally reported in https://github.com/gitextensions/gitextensions/issues/8680. 

If an application has multiple toolbars, and those are placed at an arbitrary location and persisted via `ToolStripManager.SaveSettings`, not all toolbars will be correctly located once `ToolStripManager.LoadSettings` is called.
E.g. on save:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/104114132-0409aa80-5355-11eb-81fb-54dc4c324249.png)

On load:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/104114140-213e7900-5355-11eb-9735-718cefab6bec.png)


**Expected behavior:**

The location of the toolbars persisted in the config must be preserved.


**Minimal repro:**

1. clone https://github.com/RussKie/Test-ToolStripLoad
1. Run the app, align both toolbars to the left one under another.
2. Stop the app.
3. Open the user.config file, located somethere at `C:\Users\<user>\AppData\Local\ToolstripLoad\ToolstripLoad_Url_<random string>\1.0.0.0`, check that both toolbars' locations are like this:
```xml
        <System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripSettings.toolsettings.ToolStripFilters>
            <setting name="Name" serializeAs="String">
                <value>ToolStripFilters</value>
            </setting>
            <setting name="Location" serializeAs="String">
                <value>7, 25</value>
            </setting>
        </System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripSettings.toolsettings.ToolStripFilters>
        <System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripSettings.toolsettings.ToolStripMain>
            <setting name="Name" serializeAs="String">
                <value>ToolStripMain</value>
            </setting>
            <setting name="Location" serializeAs="String">
                <value>7, 0</value>
            </setting>
        </System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripSettings.toolsettings.ToolStripMain>
```
4. Run the app again and observe the bottom toolbar shifted by few pixels to the right.
5. Close the app and see that the location value for `ToolStripFilters` has changed.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Incorrect toolbar location when restored via `ToolStripManager.LoadSettings`" (#4449)

Issues.Title: Incorrect toolbar location at 125%+ scale factor
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/docs/issue-guide.md -->

Presumably all versions:
* .NET Framework: 4.6.1 (tested)
* .NET Version: 5.0 (tested)


**Problem description:**

Originally reported in https://github.com/gitextensions/gitextensions/issues/8680. 

An application with two toolbars placed on the same lane, one after another. When the app is run in scaled environments (i.e. 125%+) the toolbars will get re-odered if the first toolbar becomes longer than the location of the second toolbar.

The same problem isn't observed at 100% scale factor, or if the repro app doesn't use its app.manifest.

* Designer:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/104089377-9ca31a80-52c2-11eb-8884-148fb2b63fc9.png)

* Runtime 100%
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/104089397-c4927e00-52c2-11eb-9b42-fede30dde77f.png)

* Runtime 150%
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/104089413-decc5c00-52c2-11eb-932f-79236d5306ad.png)


**Expected behavior:**

The order of the toolbars set at the design time must be preserved.

A workaround is to remove all toolbars after `InitializeComponent();` and add them back in the correct order, e.g.:
```cs
        public FormBrowse()
        {
            InitializeComponent();

            this.toolPanel.TopToolStripPanel.Controls.Clear();
            this.toolPanel.TopToolStripPanel.Controls.Add(this.ToolStripFilters);
            this.toolPanel.TopToolStripPanel.Controls.Add(this.ToolStripMain);

        }
```

**Minimal repro:**

1. clone https://github.com/RussKie/Test-ToolStripOrder
2. run the app at 100% - observe  `ToolStripMain` before `ToolStripFilters`
3. run the app at 150%+ - observe the reverse order of toolbars
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Incorrect toolbar location at 125%+ scale factor" (#4446)
